Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Geochemistry and Tectonics of Cretaceous Gateway Closure in the Central American Isthmus
Award.AbstractNarration:
Planet Earth is divided in three main layers at great depth, the core, the mantle and the crust. The dynamics of the mantle exerts significant control over the evolution of the crust, which in turn shapes the morphology of the surface we see today. Although rare, exposed mantle is found where dramatic tectonic events such as continental collisions have taken place, and these places are essentially windows into our planet. This study will focus on the Santa Elena Peninsula, Costa Rica, a practically unexplored segment of exposed mantle. The observations on the surface will provide valuable information about processes that result in volcanic activity. One goal is to link the Central American geologic history to the development of land-bridges and seaway closures that affected the evolution of global circulation, climate and ecology.

These researchers will explore the paleogeography and tectonic evolution of the region through geochemical, petrologic and structural analysis of mantle and associated volcanic rocks of the Santa Elena Peninsula, Costa Rica. This will be the first time the Santa Elena mantle section will be studied with modern analytical techniques. The objectives are to constrain the timing and tectonic environment of formation and consolidation of this terrane. To address these questions the investigators will map the different lithologies and conduct detailed structural analysis. Selected samples of mantle peridotites and other ultramafic lithologies will be studied with electron-microprobe and in-situ laser ablation ICP-MS. Samples from the volcanic units will be analyzed for major, trace element and radiogenic isotope compositions. The analyses will constrain the age of the different lithologies and also the tectonic events that amalgamated the Santa Elena complex. The identification of the complex with a fore-arc, back-arc or mid-ocean ridge tectonic setting will help constrain the large-scale tectonic geometry that led to the closure of the first Central American Gateway during the Cretaceous.

Collaborative Research: Geochemistry and Tectonics of Cretaceous Gateway Closure in the Central American Isthmus

Intellectual Merit

This project was a modest undertaking to study a crucial set of rocks that record a particular moment of geologic time. Like Forrest Gump, the rocks of the Santa Elena Peninsula in Costa Rica (Figure 1) have borne witness to and been part of some of the crucial geologic events of the Cenozoic Era. These include the opening and closure of the land link between North and South America, and the related evolution of the marine gateway between the Atlantic (earlier the proto-Atlantic) and the Pacific Oceans. These events influenced both the migration of early land mammals (this is known as the Great American Interchange) and the evolution of Earth's climate, as marine thermohaline circulation patterns changed due to the opening and then closing of the Panama marine gateway.

Field work was carried out in the 2010 and 2011 field seasons. Several UH students working on other projects accompanied us on the field portion, including Mr. Matthew Loocke, now a Ph.D. candidate at Cardiff University, Mr. Andy Keregyarto, now a Ph.D. student at UH (and holder of a NASA gradauate fellowship). Senior participants included Dr. Yumiko Harigane, postdoc on another project, there as part of her postdoctoral mentoring plan, and Dr. Jinny Sisson, director of the UH Geoscience Learning Center Dr. Percy Denyer, University of Costa Rica and Dr. Esteban Gazel, our primary collaborator at Virginia Tech.

Two sets of rocks were studied (a third was by our collaborative partners at Virginia Tech): The mantle peridotites of the Santa Elena ophiolite and the younger marine turbidites of the Rivas and Brito formations that lie on top of them.

The Santa Elena Ophiolite is a body of rocks similar in nature to the deepest parts of the ocean crust (over 7 km deep), rocks that have melted in order to form the volcanic rocks that make up ocean floor (Figure 2). During the gateway opening and closing events, these rocks have become exposed in outcrop at the surface, while still recording information about the configuration of the tectonic plates that eventually led to the closure of the land bridge. This formed the basis of the Masters thesis of Mr. Shawn Wright and the Senior Honors thesis of Ms. Samantha Cunningham.

The Rivas and Brito turbidites are marine sandstones containing fragments of the same minerals found in the peridotites. This is because these detrital minerals have been weathered from rocks exposed on land and transported by rivers to the marine environment. They thus record information on the rocks they were weathered from that existed in the Paleocene, but are either eroded or covered by recent volcanoes now. They are shown to be a combination of a mesozoic arc with an ophiolite sequence different from the one exposed at Santa Elena.
